unnormalised: **Environmental News Snippet: Saving Our Wild Things!**
normalised: **Environmental News Snippet: Saving Our Wild Things!**

unnormalised: Hey folks, big news on the wildlife front! Remember how worried we were about the Bengal tiger population dwindling? Well, the Wildlife Institute of India (WII) just released some encouraging data. Apparently, conservation efforts around the Bandhavgarh National Park in Madhya Pradesh are really paying off.
normalised: Hey folks, big news on the wildlife front! Remember how worried we were about the Bengal tiger population dwindling? Well, the Wildlife Institute of India (W I I) just released some encouraging data. Apparently, conservation efforts around the Bandhavgarh National Park in Madhya Pradesh are really paying off.

unnormalised: The tiger population is slowly but surely increasing! Kudos to the forest rangers and local communities working tirelessly. They're even using camera traps – imagine catching a glimpse of a majestic tiger that way!
normalised: The tiger population is slowly but surely increasing! Kudos to the forest rangers and local communities working tirelessly. They are even using camera traps – imagine catching a glimpse of a majestic tiger that way!

unnormalised: Speaking of glimpses, remember that Salman Khan movie "Tiger Zinda Hai"? While a bit dramatized, it did bring attention to the importance of wildlife conservation.
normalised: Speaking of glimpses, remember that Salman Khan movie "Tiger Zinda Hai"? While a bit dramatized, it did bring attention to the importance of wildlife conservation.

unnormalised: This isn't just about tigers, though. Elephants in Kerala, rhinos in Assam – they all need our help. Poaching is still a huge threat, and habitat loss is a major problem. Let's hope these positive trends continue and inspire more action to protect our incredible wildlife heritage for generations to come. We need to protect our national animal for future generations. More action items are necessary!
normalised: This isn't just about tigers, though. Elephants in Kerala, rhinos in Assam – they all need our help. Poaching is still a huge threat, and habitat loss is a major problem. Let's hope these positive trends continue and inspire more action to protect our incredible wildlife heritage for generations to come. We need to protect our national animal for future generations. More action items are necessary!
